update.description:
This tutorial describes how to set the velocity or joint using three methods.

* The first is an instantaneous method that does not apply forces or torques.
* The second is a perfect velocity controller that only works using ODE
* The third is by applying forces using PID controllers.
update.title: Set velocity tutorial

content.raw: I probably won't have time to take a deep look into this for the next week or two, but the added section to the beginning and the new gifs look awesome! Since the tutorial already looked pretty good to me before, I'll approve it without going through the whole thing again :)
content.html: I probably won't have time to take a deep look into this for the next week or two, but the added section to the beginning and the new gifs look awesome! Since the tutorial already looked pretty good to me before, I'll approve it without going through the whole thing again :)

content.html: @chapulina @scpeters anything else you'd like to see on this? It would be great to land this.

content.html: That's a great overview now Shane. The tutorial makes sense to me and I expect I'd be able to implement this if I wanted to.

content.raw: I mean method number 2, perfect velocity control with effort limits
content.html: I mean method number 2, perfect velocity control with effort limits

content.raw: I think this feature exists in bullet, but we just don't have it enabled
content.html: I think this feature exists in bullet, but we just don't have it enabled

content.raw: Yeah that would be great!
content.html: Yeah that would be great!

content.raw:
Gazebo 7 accepts ignition-math 2, but it has many API calls, including some used here, which only accept gazebo math. While on Gazebo 8 these calls have been deprecated... 

The use of Gazebo math has been discouraged since we started supporting ignition, so I think we should only use it where strictly necessary, such as old API calls.

So I guess the only solution is to create two separate tutorials... How about starting with one just for Gazebo 7 and adding another for Gazebo 8 later?
content.html:
Gazebo 7 accepts ignition-math 2, but it has many API calls, including some used here, which only accept gazebo math. While on Gazebo 8 these calls have been deprecated...

The use of Gazebo math has been discouraged since we started supporting ignition, so I think we should only use it where strictly necessary, such as old API calls.

So I guess the only solution is to create two separate tutorials... How about starting with one just for Gazebo 7 and adding another for Gazebo 8 later?

content.raw:
Oh I didn't realize this would be too much trouble. I'm fine with leaving it the way it is. But just as future reference, the site also supports html tables, see an example:

* Code: #!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/annotate/80a94085e105eb4532a60ebede07752b5164c0e7/ros_urdf/tutorial.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#tutorial.md-155
* Rendered: http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=ros_urdf#HeaderofaURDFFile

content.raw: I tried but long column names render poorly on the tutorials site. The top row reads "TypeNumber of Axes". What do you think about abbreviating to `Num Axes`? I could also try padding with `$nbsp;` to see if I can keep the column names from running into each other.
content.html: I tried but long column names render poorly on the tutorials site. The top row reads "TypeNumber of Axes". What do you think about abbreviating to Num Axes? I could also try padding with $nbsp; to see if I can keep the column names from running into each other.

content.raw:
Great work! It looks like you did some pretty exhaustive research!

The only thing I've noticed is that there is a lot of information and this might be overwhelming for users. There are hints here and there mentioning why one method would be preferred over another, but in general, someone looking at this for the first time might be confused as to what method they should choose, what are the pros and cons and so on. I do realize this is not easy to put together though.
content.html:
Great work! It looks like you did some pretty exhaustive research!

The only thing I've noticed is that there is a lot of information and this might be overwhelming for users. There are hints here and there mentioning why one method would be preferred over another, but in general, someone looking at this for the first time might be confused as to what method they should choose, what are the pros and cons and so on. I do realize this is not easy to put together though.

content.raw: Did you give the [JointController](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/e0036a34fdab757971fa56d4b75612bd96f8b3a3/gazebo/physics/JointController.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default) a try?
content.html: Did you give the JointController a try?

content.raw:
It would be interesting to provide an example which users can use straight away. This looks like it still requires the user to write some of their own code until they can use it right?

In fact, I think all the functions added here are super useful for a lot of people, and it might be worth it porting them to Gazebo eventually.
content.html:
It would be interesting to provide an example which users can use straight away. This looks like it still requires the user to write some of their own code until they can use it right?

In fact, I think all the functions added here are super useful for a lot of people, and it might be worth it porting them to Gazebo eventually.

content.raw: On Gazebo 8+, this accepts `ignition::math`
content.html: On Gazebo 8+, this accepts ignition::math

content.raw: I think it's best to use `ignition::math` on the examples and call `.Ign()` to convert to `gazebo::math` as needed. Note that `gazebo::math` is fully deprecated on Gazebo 8.
content.html: I think it's best to use ignition::math on the examples and call .Ign() to convert to gazebo::math as needed. Note that gazebo::math is fully deprecated on Gazebo 8.
